description:
The Food
There's a good variety of clay pots to choose, from your main meats of beef, pork, and chicken to anything like seafood, frog, and even pig's feet. One special service they have is the small pot of soup they bring at the beginning for free (call it appetizer if you will) while you wait for your food. The soup is light with pork, carrots, bean curds, and yellow beans. For the clay pots, I've tried few different ones here before, and they were all pretty good. But the Taishan Yellow Eel (黄鳝饭) is my go-to dish because I like Eels, and the dish bring back a nostalgic hometown taste.

The Service and Restaurant
The service in general is normal and good. The food comes out to table in a reasonable time. Out of all the time I've been there, I have yet to have a bad experience with their service. The restaurant quite spacious with good amount of room and lighting. There are different size tables to accommodate various party sizes.

The Menu and Price
There are a few places around the area that serves clay pot dishes, but not so much clay pot rice. The Claypot House is of a niche place that serves clay pot rice and have a good variety. Along with their clay pot rice, they also have Steamed Lotus Leaf Dishes, Taishan Specialty Dishes, and variety of Soups. Though the prices of these dishes are not what you would call cheap, I believe they are still reasonably priced.
author: Food W.

description:
Food is pretty good, the claypot rice is very nice.

But when I ask for extra sauce, I want extra sauce. I only asked for extra because they provide ALMOST none for takeout orders. Now I asked for extra and barely got anymore. Super frustrating.

I'll update next time accordingly.
author: Austin M.

description:
My favorite spot for clay pot rice.

My usuals are the lamb clay pot and the beef clay pot. It won't disappoint. I love the crispy rice that builds up around the pot too. The chili soy sauce is also bomb.
author: Mabel Y.

description: I came to claypot house on a Saturday night for dinner with my family. When we came there was no wait and a good amount of tables were empty. The menu is not extremely big which is a good thing because big menus are extremely overwhelming. I ordered three clay pot rices. They were really delicious and the flavor was extravagant. The waiters was pretty friendly and helpful. The atmosphere is definitely a little outdated and cluttered but the food is very delicious! Overall I would come back to try more of the clay pot Rice's.
author: Carissa C.

description:
Came here and got a couple of clay pots, one was pork ribs and the other was eel and chinese sausage. Also got the duck here.

Let's start out with the duck. For the sake of the review, I'm going to pretend I never got the duck. The meat was fine (maybe a little on the tough side) but the sauce was really bad. It was sweet and thick. Combining that with duck just didn't sit well. Maybe it's authentic, but I won't be getting this type of duck again.

The clay pots are mostly rice and some meat. Like others have mentioned 70/30 split is about right. The rice is somewhat seasoned with soy sauce and the sauce from the meat (definitely oily from the meat which is great!). The bottom has some of the crunchier rice pieces. It's not the same as the crunchy pieces in bibimbap and instead it's like a thin layer of hard rice. It wasn't great, but wasn't bad either. It did add a little uniqueness. Given that each clay pot was about 11 bucks, the price seemed fair too. The meat between the two clay pots were relatively the same and enjoyed both. 

If you stick to clay pots and are ok with mainly eating rice 4*'s. Otherwise, might be a 2 or 3 star
author: Victor D.

description:
Tons of Taishan classics here that I grew up with. It definitely hit a soft spot that made me miss home and my mom's cooking. 

Service was really fast and our server was really friendly. 

Dinner comes with complimentary soup and absolutely love the soy sauce with marinated jalapenos. 

Ordered two claypots and a veggies dish
1) Spareribs, Chinese sausage, pork and duck. 
2) Salty fish with pork patty
3) Snow pea leaves with garlic 

Both claypots were really good, but it didn't come with enough meat and toppings. There was way more rice than there were toppings. I'd say probably 70% rice and 30% toppings. 

My favorite part of claypot is the crispy and crunchy rice at the bottom of the pot. Sadly, both dishes didn't come with that.
author: Bonnie T.

description:
Authentic Taishan (a part of Canton province in China) food - claypot rice. The place is in the heart of Richmond and among the growing Chinese neighborhood, surrounded by tons of other great Chinese restaurants. Just coming back from HK and craving for some crispy claypot rice, we chose to try this place out.

On a Sunday morning, this place was fairly busy - local Chinese family hanging out, young people chilling. The service was fast and good. We ordered Yuzu tea and red bean smoothie for drinks. Yuzu tea was good but red bean smoothie tastes weird and stale. We got bitter melon stew as vegetable - it was huge portion but cooking was mediocre. Ingredients look a bit unfresh and the taste is underwhelming and blend. Bitter melon was overcooked.

For rice, we ordered lotus leave wrapped lamp rice and yellow eel claypot rice. The lamb rice had an excessive amount of rice and the lamb was a bit hard to chew and came with too much fat - I thought lamb was supposed to be tender. The eel rice was probably the only memorable dish of the meal (and granted it's their must-order dish). This eel is not the Japanese type of Unagi eel - yellow eel is much smaller so it comes in tens and hundreds of them. Eel is super fresh and tender. Very umami. Rice is very crispy and blends perfectly with the eel juice. A bit oily though.

I'd order the eel dish again but don't think would go back intentionally.
author: Shen Q.

description:
I was utterly surprised by how great this mom and pop Chinese restaurant was! We came at around 6pm for an early dinner on a weekday, and there wasn't any wait. The restaurant is quite old and dirty on the inside, but the food definitely makes up for its appearance. 

I ordered the lamb stew claypot rice and my friend ordered the classic Chinese sausage/ bacon, porks ribs, and duck claypot rice. We ordered a portion for one, so that we could try two different ones. Each pot was about $10-12, and the portions were enough for two people for each pot (if you're a smaller eater like my friend and me). The waiters first gave us a soup that was free of charge, made with tofu skin and carrots. Since we were both freezing from walking outside, the soup definitely hit the spot. The claypot rices took around 10-15 minutes to make, and when it came to the table, I could smell the amazing aroma of the charcoaled rice and meats. The lamb stew pot came with a good amount of meat, and the rice was extra crispy. My friend's pot was more aromatic, with the fatty bacon and sausage seeping into the rice, but nonetheless, both were amazing. 

Pro tip for first time claypot rice eaters: let the rice sit on the hot claypot for a while before trying to scoop it out of the pot! This allows for the rice to char and get crispy on the bottom. 

For the amazing prices, the great portions, and a memorable childhood food, I will definitely be back!
author: Sandra S.

description: Well I was visiting from LA and wanted to see if they have good claypot rice. So I ended in this restaurant. The server is really nice. The food is so so I expect it to be better since it is SF chinatown. However, after comparing my conclusion is the claypot rice in Arcadia in los angeles name"mei mei qui", they have the best claypot rice by far!! They even include some vegetable on top of the rice and the server will mixed the rice with the black sauce, omg soooo yummy. Sorry.
author: Dee L.

description:
My friend and I decided to try this place because it was features in a youtube video that my friend saw. Coming in on a Sunday evening, this place was packed - a good sign. We were seated shortly and placed an order for the clay pot with spareribs, sausauge, pork and duck. The food came out shortly after and piping hot. 

My only complaint was the portion sizes. Sure they fill the bowl with loads of rice (could easily feed 4), but the meat was overly skimpy. At most there was 10 pieces total and the pieces were more bone than meat. Pretty plain as well.

Maybe it was an off night or they ran out of meat, but won't be coming back.
author: Alan N.

description: If youre ever in the area for a date or quick lunch break then def try this restaurant.  The pots are amazing esp spareribs preserved chinese sausage pork and duck... bon appetit
author: Eugenia L.

description: Stopped in for lunch yesterday before hitting the museum.  The place looked promising, was not full and two servers.  5 parties came in after we were seated.  4 ordered before us and were served their food before we ended up being served.  Our wait for attention to order was 20 minutes another 30 before we were served.  In seeing the yelp reviews, we did not get the complimentary soup as all the other tables did.  The claypot spareribs in black bean sauce was okay, skimpy on the spare ribs and the rice on the bottom of the claypot was burned.  I mean black burned.  The seafood combo was pretty good, a nice kick of ginger in the sauce.  Now, I rarely expect friendly service, usually it is perfunctory and that is okay.  In this place it really felt like our business was not welcome.  Weird.  Not sure we will be coming back.
author: Donna H.

description: The only Taishanese claypot place I found in SF.  Compared to the other claypot places I've tried, this is the best one. :)
author: Shu S.

description:
The clay pot casserole is essentially comfort food for Cantonese cuisine. You can't go wrong with crispy charred rice mixed with meat. This restaurant does a good job with the clay pot. The meat to rice ratio was 1:1, had a good deal of charred rice that was not too burnt. In addition there was enough flavor as we did not need to add soy sauce. We ordered the #6, spareribs, sausage, all the basics. Highly recommend as the go to if it's your first time trying clay pot casserole.

We also ordered the bitter melon and beef. The bitter melon was extremely fresh. It was not too bitter, the texture was soft and grainy, indicating it isn't too young or old. Beef was soft and tender as well.

The last dish we ordered was the salt and pepper fish. The fish was also very fresh. The breading and fish was soft, airy and moist. However I found the seasoning to be a bit too salty.

They do provide you with a pot of chicken soup, free of charge. The soup had a bit too much msg and not enough natural chicken flavor.

Overall great experience. It gets busy and packed, especially since the clay pot takes an average of 20 minutes to make from scratch.
author: Ann M.

description: Over priced and overcharged us! They didn't even have a "cook" working so all they had available was steamed food. So disappointed. Will not go back to this place.
author: Ariel V.

description:
The lone server in our late night visit was very friendly, helpful and patience (even though it was 40 minutes to closing).
They are known for their clay pot rice. So, it is not a surprise that the menu is heavily on clay pot rice and lotus leaf rice. 
They do have some other dishes but shouldn't be the main focus of your visit.
We had chicken and mushrooms clay pot, pork ribs and rice in lotus leaf, and stir fried lotus roots with other fresh vegetables.  Both the clay pot and the pork ribs were very good. The lotus roots could have been better. It was a bit bland for our taste.
All three dishes were made with some preserved meat/sausage for flavor. So, if you are not a fan of preserved meat, then might want to think twice before visiting.
author: Andrew L.

description:
We were looking for a place to eat for dinner and found this on Clement. My friend also recommended it to us.

We sat down and ordered. They gave us this soup as an appetizer with the meal and that was alright. Nothing too special.

Our food came out and initially we were very happy with the food! It was very tasty and the rice was very crispy from the claypot. As we continued to eat, we came to realize that we meat served in the clay pot was overly salty. I thought it was this way because the rice cuts down on the saltiness, but it was just too salty at times. Had to chug my water on some bites.

Overall, food was cheap and pretty good. The clay pot we ordered was good but the rice kept getting stuck in my teeth and was salty at times.
author: Don H.

description: The rice is dry, lacks sauce, chicken w/dried mushroom only has 2 mushrooms. I wouldn't recommend it to anyone nor will I be back. No bueno.
author: Susan H.

description: They used to give more meat filling on top of their clay pots. If you love rice like Hubby does, the pan the $12 a pot is worth it. He got the spare rib clay pot and I got the salted chicken. It was a scrawny chicken which was too salty and more bones than meat. The green onion sauce over it was good. The 2 clay pots were more than enough. Their complimentary soup is my fav here and they gave us a small dish of braised lettuce.  There are not many clay pot places around so this is a neighborhood gem.
author: Ry T.

description: we ordered the eggplant dish, mixed seafood in lotus leaf, and claypot rice with spareribs/chinese sausage, and preserved duck; the eggplant was tasty, the mixed seafood had way more rice than actual seafood, and the claypot rice is tasty.
author: Allison C.

description:
Authentic and tasty clay pots. 

Their menu has a good selection with pictures ! But they have some f***ed up tables. They have to use tape to tape the surface of them. Time to get some new tables ! Service kinda sucks. But can't blame the waiter since he was the only 1 working Monday night. Poor guy was doing everything and running all over the place. Every time I needed something had to walk up to the counter. 

Complimentary soup before the entrees arrive. It was pretty good. 

Ordered: 
Yellow eel & Chinese sausage clay pot 
Taishan special pig stomach 

The yellow eel & Chinese sausage clay pot was so yummy! Tons of flavor. Could have more ingredients though with the amount of rice they give you. A clay pot can be shared between 1-2 people. The rice is cooked perfectly. When you get to the bottom the rice is crispy! On point !! The taishan special pig stomach was good as well to eat with the rice. It had plenty of flavor and not too chewy! Just the way I like it. Watch out for some of the peppers -so spicy !! Will definitely be back to try their other clay pots.
author: Karen L.

description:
You would think a place called Claypot House would have yummy and legit claypot, and YES, this place was pretty good. I ordered number 1, 6 and 14. The food came out pretty quick actually. If I went to a dim sum place or another restaurant that doesn't specialize in claypot, it would take around 30 minutes or so. 

Number 6 was super tasty, much variety of flavor and ingredients, and is definitely my favorite out of all three. For portion size of the claypot, decent amount to share one pot for two people max. There were 4 of us, so we ordered 3 different claypots. Their rice was pretty crispy, and was not burnt to the point where it was black, so to me it's made just right! 

There's one waiter guy who mostly helped us, he's quick and knew how to do his job well, great service!
author: Vanessa L.

description: Recommended by a friend who loved this place. It certainly did not disappoint. It claims to be authentic Toishan food. I'm not from Toishan, so I can't speak to that. But it is one of the better claypot rice I've had in the US. It's a small mom and pop restaurant with surprisingly good food. We ordered the mushroom and chicken as well as the spare ribs combo pot. Both were so tasty and flavorful. I especially like the texture of the rice cooked in claypot, when it soaks in flavor of the meat and vegetables while being cooked. Adding more soy sauce if you find it too bland. It's nice to order two different single pots and share with your friend or partner, and there will be some to take home as well!
author: Priscilla L.

description:
I have been eating at this place for about 8years, from old location to new location...
took my parents there, and friends from out of town...come here for lunch/dinner when I hang out with friends too...
I like this place a lot because the clay pot rice has the most closest taste from my hometown Toishan...yet, it impresses me even more on my last visit which was yesterday...

As we walked in the store, the last table was on their way out. I asked a staff if they were close for the day. The owner and staff both said they would have us as their last customers for the day and sat us down. I feel sorry for holding the store open for another hour for only two of us, and thankful for their great customer services and FOOD definitely...after we paid, I told the owner that we drove all the way from East Bay just for this meal(this is how much i like their food, no doubt)...

5stars for both customer services and GREAT FOOD(the main reason that attracts me there)...
author: Yasan W.

description:
Solid and genuine taishan Chinese clay pot rice. Gets busy at peak hours. The flavors are good but gets heavy on rice and light on veggies. Would rather have Claypot without rice and just eat the rice as a supplement of choice.

The salt fish and pork patty was good but I preferred the lamb stew. The house special  mixed vegetables was a good way to balance out the heavy carbs.
author: Keo N.

description: Went into check out this spot as I heard they were good. Waited 10 minutes for a table, no one was ahead of us and there were just 3 of us. After 5 minutes another party  of 2 showed up. They were seated and we were ignored. For this reason I left and am leaving my first negative review.
author: Apollonio L.

description:
Yummy claypot rice!

* * * EXPERIENCE * * *
- It gets pretty packed during dinner time
- Free soup: I still can't figure out whether they provide free soup every time. There were instances I got it when I went at lunch time during weekend, but I also did not get it once or twice when I went at dinner time on a weekday. Better to ask next time.
- Pretty friendly staff, but sometimes they would be having lunch/dinner time at the corner and they couldn't see what's going on at the inner part of restaurant. But if you try to get their attention they are usually happy to serve you.

* * * FOOD * * *
Eel and Chinese sausage rice in clay pot 黃鱔臘味煲仔飯: A-
While they are both eels, this eel is not the same you would get from a Japanese eel bento box. These "yellow eels" are usually from small rivers, ponds or even mud holes, so if they are not processed well or if they aren't fresh there will be some gamey or mud-ish type of taste. But I've tried a few times here and they were all pretty fresh to me. Chinese sausage is good as always (I don't think you can mess this up). Of course, main point of clay pot rice is at the bottom - where there's supposed to be a thin slice of slightly-overcooked rice. I'm glad to report that this restaurant never failed to have this important element included in the claypot! 

I tried getting other dishes like stir-fry vegetables, but there were just meh so I would say don't bother with other things on the menu. Their claypot rice dishes are already to the point!
author: Simon C.

description:
We tried this spot on a rainy night and right from the start were wary due to the chill inside- we came because of a recommendation by the local paper to try another type of Chinese regional cooking .So sitting in warm jackets we decided to order two different clay pots( actually they are cast iron). First came complimentary lukewarm soup- another 
bad sign. The entrees were terrible- greasy lamb  stew was mostly gristle and bone and the other a mishmash of unidentifiable scraps of animal parts. There was lots of rice and the bottom does crust to the pot. Not recommended.
author: Helen M.

description: It's not bad...my peeps aren't from toisan and we don't eat claypot at home so I can't say too much about it. The claypot we had included chicken and mushrooms, that was good! But who doesn't like chicken and mushrooms???? The seafood tofu dish was eh. I guess for the price you can't expect real fish paste, the fish balls were the kind you would get for $2/bag and the mix of seafood and tofu sauce was a little too salty for me. The soup was not very warm but it was kind of tasty, would have been tastier if it was hot. It had dried bok Choy, carrots...overall I would only recommend getting the claypot and apparently the eel is the most traditional so perhaps I'll get that next time.
author: Kylie L.

description:
its really just a 3 star place, but ill throw in an extra star for being unique in SF.

the place looks like a hole in the wall. utensils and tables are not what one would call pristine.

the clay pot rice, while good, could be better with a little more meat and some sauce so the rice has some more flavor. id say this place was better before the move to this location.
author: Jason C.

description:
Super good!!!!! Recommended!

Typical taste from Hong Kong claypot!! Rice is not sticky, very crunchy! Yumyum. They also serve soup of the day for the table.

I don't know why the rating is not high, at least 4*. This place serve superb claypots meal!!
author: Lillian N.

description: The claypot rice is so good! Any time I'm in San Francisco I come here.  Good service relaxed atmosphere I always feel so welcome which is not always the case.  My favorite is the spare rib/sausage/duck.  You might have to chase them down for water, but totally worth it. Reasonable prices too!
author: Stef S.

description:
Got ripped off today!  The food was just ok for the hole in a wall.  Utensils weren't clean, tea was cold and I got ripped off. The guy was out of pea sprouts
And suggested yam leaves.  I thought yam leaves would be the same price or lower, but we were charged $20 for a dish of yam leaves.  Won't come back ever.
author: Fiona N.

description:
The staff is friendly in this hole-ish-in-a-wall place.   The namesake dish delivers on the crispy rice, but it, like most of our dishes, came with a hefty helping of salt and oil that made it hard to finish.  

The exception is the salt pepper tofu. It is well done and crispy.  I'd recommend it.
author: S F.

description:
I bought a take out order of ribs/Lop Mei rice last weekend.  The order contained about 3 pieces of fatty Lop Yuk (pork) and maybe another piece or two of sausage.   This is far different from what is served in the restaurant and seems to be a complete rip off.   

I will not give this place my business again.

Stop scamming your customers!
author: Joseph W.

description: The best rice claypot in Bay Area! Must try the 滑鸡煲，排骨腊味煲！they will serve you complimentary soup too!
author: Jasmine C.

description:
Growing up, my favorite thing to eat was CLAYPOT RICE! Towards the end, the rice that is stick to the claypot is amazing too. crispy and crunchy. Its not like the ones you have in Asia but its pretty good. The soy sauce is flavorfun to add to the rice but not over powering. My favorites is the spareribs and or "lop may". YUM! It takes longer to make so order something else first, like their veggie dishes, my favorite is "tong choy". It taste really good. Seasonal. The seafood tofu pot is good too. I actually think most of their food taste pretty good. Also they give you free soup. Different daily. 

Services is lacking but its a super causal chinese restaurant. Don't expect great services. haha
author: Sandy B.

description: This is the first time I have eaten clay pot rice and all I have to say is I'm a BIG Fan. I ordered #4 Eel and Chinese Sausage. The food came in a hot pot, smell was so aromatic, eel and Chinese sausage tasteful. The portion of rice in the pot was humongous and honestly so flavorful since the meat was cooked in the pot the juices from these meats was in the rice making it so delicious just to eat the fried Claypot rice itself. This place is a gem in the city. My first time eating this type of food and I'm a huge fan.
author: Jennifer N.

description: I walk by this place all the time and it always seems to be busy. Finally got a chance to try it today.  The rice clay pots are so flavorful and the best part is the crispy rice at the bottom.  They don't give you much on the toppings, mostly rice.
author: Kim T.

description:
Everytime I'm in NorCal this is a mandatory stop for me! There's no place that makes their Claypot like this place in SoCal. I always get the spareribs in Claypot rice. It does take awhile to be made but they serve you free soup so you wouldn't be as hungry while you wait for your food. Claypot takes about 20minutes to be done so be prepared! I wouldn't come here if it took 5 minutes to make..

Service could be a little slow. When I talk in English to get the check and a togo box they took awhile to the point where I have to ask aggressively in Chinese.
author: Johnson D.

description:
This was my first time here, but we went with my sister and her husband, who came here frequently in the past. I've tried claypot rice before at another location in Sacramento, but while it was good, this place is better. The rice here does not stick to the claypot (well, most of it doesn't) and it's not too oily either. It's quite flavorful and we had two different claypots--eel and some sort of pork (maybe pork belly?). We also ordered the eel and pork and frog rice wrapped in lotus leaves. Oh, and some stir fried yam vines/ leaves dish and fried frog legs. (Sorry, I didn't pay attention to their menu names.) 

Everything smelled great. Even the frog legs smelled and tasted goodt! I'm usually not an amphibious fan because the taste is oddly swampy and earthy to me, but the fried frog legs were so yummy! They didn't taste like chicken, but they didn't taste like frogs either :) 

The claypot rice dishes were delectable. They were well seasoned and I thought there was plenty of meat in there. The best part is the toasted rice that you scrape from the sides of the claypot. Don't worry, there is little effort needed to scrape the rice off. I don't know how they did it without making the rice too oily, but it came off quite easily! 

I ate and ate until I was bursting at the seams, but we still had plenty of leftovers to take home. The veggies were okay, but whatever, we weren't really there for the veggies :D I'd love to come back!
author: Myha D.

description:
Remember when this place was across the street in a much smaller space?  Remember when they were in Outer Richmond, where Hakka is now?  Remember when this corner location was a pho place?  I'm happy to see "The Claypot House" occupy this space in Inner Richmond.  It's much closer to everything else, especially if you want to pick up dim sum to go, boba, banh mi's, or donuts nearby.

I love this place, love all their claypot dishes.  The owner is always happy and friendly.  The menu has pictures if you're not sure what to order, and the owner is always present to explain and make a few suggestions.
author: Christine R.

description:
Quick service and good food we especially enjoyed the clay pot, with tofu braised

Also the soy sauce is accented with  marinated jalapeños

All kinds of authentic Chinese delicacies  are here

If you're a food snob stay away
author: Joe T.

description: As a Toishanese who is obsessed with yellow eel rice pot, I have to write a review for this place. It is not comparable to the original yellow eel rice pot in Toishanese, HOWEVER, this is the best one I have had in the US where they don't have fresh yellow eel. I would recommend it to my friends and families who are planning to visit SF!
author: Crabby L.

description:
Decided to try this spot for the first time. Ordered pig stomach black
Pepper soup and pig tail in lotus leaf. Disappointment... THe man taking my order who is
Probably the owner was VERY friendly and I feel bad
For this review. The soup was completely bland with maybe 3-4 tiny pieces of pig
Stomach with less than half of broth in the tiny receptacle
It was served in ( and cost the most!!) the pigs tail was tasty HOWEVER half of
The dish consisted of
Some sort of cheap sausage that I did not order. It's like they decided to save some money on me (even though pig tail is dirt cheap) or just ran out of pig tails for the day. At least tell me there's something else in my food! Cmon guys... I wish I could of given you a better rating. But this is not acceptable.
author: Paul S.

description:
Who doesn't like claypot rice specials....

We ordered the eel special.....my friend ate the whole thing....
and the preserved veggies with pork.....I also finished mine....that was how good it was....

The reason I couldn't give it a higher star rating was because of the cleanliness....lacks for sure....another were the damn flies all over.....
author: Leslie Y.

description: half duch is very big and taste so good a little bit sour but made you can not stop eatingn
author: Nattakarn N.

description:
yummy clay pot! ended up here after another place we wanted to go to had a long wait. the service was okay, a bit slow. 

the food was really good. i'd recommend the clay pots...ordered the fried chicken pieces and it was a little too greasy. 

i didn't get soup when i was here...will have to look into what we order next time to see if we get that too!
author: Vanessa S.

description: I must vote this as one of the MOST FILTHIEST restaurant on Clement Street.  I almost slipped as I walked in due to the floor grease.  The tables and chairs are either ripped, cracked, holes and tapped on with clear tape and greasy.  Food wait time was about 25 minutes around 1:30pm (there was only total 3 tables occupied).  Will not go again.
author: JLcam T.

description:
My bestie's BF loves the clay pot here, so I was convinced to give it a try. 
She ordered the House Special Rice Clay Pot for me.
(It comes with Taishan Yellow Eel, preserved Chinese Sausage, Pork and Frog Legs) 4/5 well cooked, very flavorful! I didn't enjoy the side order soup that came with it. 
Most likely be back for something else.
author: Elaine Y.

description:
Clay pot rice dishes are like pure comfort food for me, just like home cooking, very authentic and satisfying. I didnt get my free complimentary bowl of soup? like another Yelper mentioned? so minus one star.

Excellent service, the food was very fresh and steaming hot when it arrived and didnt take too long, maybe 15 minutes max.

Im glad they have this new Clay Pot House restaurant, since the Taishan Cafe closed, this is pretty much the same type of restaurant, I'll definitely come back to try the other interesting array of Chinese / Taishan dishes

I like places like this, nothing fancy, just great food and casual atmosphere.

the prices are pretty reasonable and you get a good meal for not much money.
author: Mr Bolo B.

description:
Hmmm my mouth waters whenever I think about this place. I've been a fan since their old location across the street when they were Taishan Cafe! Then it burnt down and I was so sad!!!

One night when I was eating at Shabu Club I saw Clay Pot House across the street. Omg I knew it was Taishan Cafe reborn and I wanted to leave Shabu Club, but too bad I ordered already. So I came the weekend after. 

Service is still not that smooth due to new spot, workflow, and staff, but menu is the same and food is just as good. Things I usually order are the spare rib Chinese sausage/preserved pork clay pot rice, bitter melon, seafood clay pot, and daikon clay pot. Free jug of soup is always a plus.

Pour some soy sauce over the food at the edge of the clay pot rice and let it cook longer so the bottom rice gets crispy. Come early before 7pm to avoid the line.
author: Iris H.

description:
Clay pot rice is excellent for cold weather like now!  This place mainly serves claypot rice (duh, hence the name!).  You can choose the dish in different sizes : personal size, small size (serves 2-3 people), medium (3-4 people) and large (5-6 people).  You can order the meal in different sizes depending the size of your party. Even if you have a huge party, you can order the small size and order different ones so you can try the different varieties.  We ordered the one with chinese sauage, chinese pork belly and preserved duck and the one with chicken and mushroom.  Both were delicious.  The meal comes with a pot of soup of the day and a plate of veggie (usually lettuce).  

Be prepared to wait at least 10-15 minutes because it does take that long to have the rice crispy on the sides, which is the best part!!
author: Jannie Q.

description:
Whats with all the negative reviews? This place is da bomb!

Free soup--I mean real soup, not the usual "sweet and sour" or "egg drop" crap, but authentic soup served in a soup pot? Check. Authentic claypot rice? Check. Nice lotus leaf rice wrapped in lotus leaves? Check. Cheap prices? Check. Clean interior? Check.

In terms of food, the quality seems to be consistent with expectations--pretty much what'd I expect in terms of decent quality claypot rice. Claypot rice is usually pretty hard to get right, so kudos to them. The minced meat was pretty flavorful, as was the preserved sausages and such!

The service was also pretty good--nothing bad I can point my fingers at. Things came promptly and the servers seemed polite. That seems to be different from other reviewers' experiences, so perhaps it might be different the next time I visit.

Keep up the good work! This is definitely the place to go if you're craving claypot rice.
author: Henry L.

description:
You know that it's legit when literally every face inside the restaurant is Chinese and all of the postings are in Chinese.  This is the most authentic Toisan restaurant I have ever been to.  Actually, come to think of it, this is the ONLY Toisan restaurant I have ever been to.  I was saddened to hear that Taishan Cafe had closed down but I am thrilled that they opened this restaurant instead.  For those of you that visited Taishan Cafe, this one is like 100X improved.  At Taishan Cafe, I thought I was literally eating out of someone's garage but here there are actually tables and servers that actually come to take your order!  Now, if you're expecting five-star service, you won't find it here.  But, you will find truly authentic home cooked Chinese food like you've never had before.

Also for anyone who was not impressed by the complimentary soup, clearly just doesn't get it.  This is not meant to be gourmet food.  This is home cooked Chinese food like from your Toisan grandma's kitchen...if you had a Toisan grandma, like myself.  And that soup was legit.  So heartwarming and comforting on a cold windy San Francisco day.  Seriously it was perfect and transported me back to my grandparents' tiny little house in ghetto DC.

The claypots are pretty generous in size and are a must to order.  Basically, instead of ordering white rice, you would order a claypot or two and eat it as a dish but also as the rice to eat with anything else you order.  The bottom of the claypot always gets a nice crispy skin to enjoy at the end of the meal.  Our favorite of the claypots was the Taishan Chicken--it was smothered in green onions...which is basically the best herb ever.  We were super impressed by the other dishes that we ordered in addition to the traditional claypots:

- Lamb Stew - really flavorful tender chunks of lamb and bean curd sheets (made from the soybeans that comprise tofu but are chewier and almost have the consistence of pasta) and lettuce. very generous portion and probably my favorite dish of the night.
- Salt & Pepper Fish - fried crisp and delicious with a great pepper/garlic/salt flavor.  We originally ordered the S&P Tofu but apparently they ran out...I'm not really sure how that's possible since they offered us other tofu dishes but just couldn't make the salt & pepper tofu dish.  Anyway, we were perfectly satisfied with the substitute of fish instead.  Absolutely delicious.
- Sweet Potato Leaves - I know it's just a veggie but it was still delicious.
author: Jess Y.

description:
You can't really complain about service because the place is literally a hole in a wall/small business owned Chinese restaurant. Typical service I would say and u literally just come here for the food. If u want good service then go to a foo fee Chinese American restaurant

On to the food --- ordered lamb stew with lettuce with no rice. Sooo effin good. Sauce and meat was very tender

Sausage and pork = salty goodness. Had the large cause we had 4 people but definitely too much rice vs meat portion. I do love the crunchy rice at the bottom!

Veggies - really flavorful

Fried pork ribs = I could and would eat the entire plate. Salty but not too salty plus it was all pork not just fatty meat

Overall, pretty good experience. Was kinda busy in the beginning but there was only two people working.

Maybe Chinese diners was just there to eat and leave. That's how it goes I suppose. Can't really complain!
author: Carol Y.

description: The signature pot is not bad compared to the authentic one I've had in taishan. But since those materials are hard to find in America I don't blame them. But they are a bit shady on the soup that's suppose to be free that comes with the meal. It was after I ordered the soup on the menu then I noticed every table around me have a pot of soup so I asked the waiter if soups are free, she hesitated for a sec and then said "oh yeah, but we ran out of them for the day. Sorry about that." Hmmm... aren't you suppose to let me know before I order the soup tho?? So other than that the taste is okay in this place. I would come back.
author: Berry P.

description:
This place definitely hits the spot.  I was a very loyal customer at their previous location, which was just a few blocks up from this location.  However, there was fire damage, and they had to relocate here.  Since then, they expanded, and added more tables and seating.  They have hired new staff as well.  The customer service is still great, but at the old location, the service deserved 5 stars.  The owner is always there and is super nice and welcoming.  

I usually order the chicken and mushroom claypot, accompanied by salt and pepper tofu.  While you wait for your food, they always give complimentary soup, which always hits the spot.  

When the claypot arrives,  you can ask them for an egg and crack it into the pot if you wish.  One must always add their jalapenos into the pot.  It adds more flavor and a little spice to the goodies.  

I highly advise everyone to come here.  This is one of my favorite places to eat at!
author: Victor L.

description:
First time to visit this restaurant on a lazy Sunday afternoon.  It was hard to find parking on Clement v Street so I decided to let where I parked guide where I had lunch.

So sat down and looked over the menu. They had quite the variety of clay pot rice. Some were they usual ones like Chinese sausage, spare ribs...But I saw the yellow eel and had to try. They also had page of interesting dishes and I tired to order the black bean sauce snail but was told not in season. So I settled on the black pepper pork stomach soup.

The soup was quite good. The black pepper flavor really came through. I thought it was missing an ingredient. I couldn't figure out what at the time but after discussing with my GF she figured it if...it needed Chinese sour vegetable. That's how it's made in Hong Kong.

The yellow eel clay pot rice was really good. Particularly after you add their special soy sauce.

I'd definitely come back here again to try their other clay pots and dishes.
author: Gerald S.

description: I think this is one of the good claypot places in SF. The ingredients are fresh and the claypot rice is tasty and has many choices on their menu. The setting of tables and seats is fine. They have a few big tables that can fit in group parties. Besides the claypot rice, they also have other dishes can choose but not that much. The prices are little pricey though as a typical small Chinese restaurant.
author: Jessie L.

description: Go to spot for clay pot in San Francisco! Takes a little while to cook but they give you free soup to tide you over. I usually get the number 6 or 7 (might be different since they changed the menu recently) which has duck, spareribs, chinese sausage, and preserved pork. A "small" size feeds 2 people perfectly.
author: Hayoung K.

description:
My, how things have changed.  
Tai Shan Restaurant is the original name of this restaurant which was located across the street.  After a fire wiped the slate clean, they moved to this larger space and modernized everything, including their I-pad order system.  I used to frequent their satellite location on Cabrillo which closed and morphed to become Hakka Restaurant.  My parents enjoyed going there as parking was convenient and the owner/host was very personable and friendly at that time.  Now toting his I-pad, the owner is all smiles when he greets his guests and takes orders.  Here's what we shared on a recent Friday evening:

Preserved meats and Chinese sausage rice (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q&select=oOi6KjQxhbvEC3UKMaL3Yg) - Classic menu selection, this is the most common version of claypot rice that families order.  With the salted meats and crusty rice that sticks to the claypot, one of the better renditions that I've had.  Be sure to add their spicy soy sauce left tableside if you like a heavier flavor.

Dried scallop pork patty rice (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q&select=6czl0qfB7ra8brv1iakXUQ) - The lightest and probably most healthy dish that we ordered for dinner.  Nothing really stood out as the dried scallop flavor was feint if at all existent.  Needed the spicy soy sauce to perk things up.

Lamb stew rice (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q&select=SsxJajGvD06-qCsE7as_cQ) - The heartiest of the three rice selections that we ordered, the lamb was tender and not at all gamey.  Liked the Yuba pieces that infused the sauce flavor and mixed well with the rice.

Steamed tofu with pork (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q&select=jUKRmWoEeVPn7H3YHJWLsQ) - Another one of the healthier dishes that we ordered, this was just okay.  Our dinner hosts who are regulars here said that the portions shrank from before (seven pieces now versus nine or ten in the past).

Lotus root and mixed vegetables (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q&select=WMOkuU7QB7Wlt55WWuMQwg) - Nice stir fry selection with a good variety of veggies including cauliflower (in season), wood ears, and snap peas.  There is Chinese sausage in this dish so it is NOT vegetarian by any means.

Preserved vegetable and pork belly (http://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) -  Artery clogging good... no really, good in a delicious way, but not so sure whether my heart can take this, Elizabeth!

The above plentifully fed our party of four and there were no leftovers to be had.  They also served us a small gourd of house soup which consisted of veggies and pork pieces.  The restaurant was about half full when we arrived but filled when we left around 8 pm.  We happened to meet two gentlemen sitting at the next table who, like me, dined here for the first time.  When we struck up a conversation about the menu, we learned that we shared many dining experiences from growing up, living, and working in Chinatown during the '70's and '80's.  You could say that this place is a bit of a throwback to the food from that time. 
The menu is pretty straightforward and they have seasonal specials like black bean snails when we were there.  Besides the traditional claypot rice, they also offer lotus wrapped rice dishes.  All of the above rice dishes had nice crispness to the bottom, though the rice above was a bit on the dry side.
The best description for this cuisine is Cantonese or Taishan comfort food.  Your parents will enjoy this cuisine if they are from Southern China.
author: Mike C.

description:
+/- THE FOOD
I ordered the Taishan yellow eel clay pot here and although it was pretty tasty, it was just okay. The eels were definitely delicious and pretty flavorful. A lot of people might think it looks/tastes really weird, but it's definitely not intimidating at all. However, the eel to rice ratio was insane........ly small. There was a thin layer of eel and a whole bucket of rice left. There was a huge lack of sauce and it was just basically a lot of white rice, making the dish hard to finish.
author: Cindy C.

description: One of the most authentic Cantonese place I have ever been to in the US. Couldn't bet better
author: Shuling C.

description: You won't get claypot rice anywhere in California so far that I have researched. If you are in San Francisco, this is the spot to swing by. We made almost three visits when visiting san francisco for some claypot rice. I know my mom and I love clay pot rice. It's a treat to eat such rice cooked in a clay pot. They have a few in Hong Kong. There are a few restaurants that have this special dish. If you want an authentic experience of eating some rice cooked in clay pot. Come on over.  There is spare ribs hot clay pot rice, chicken with chinese sausage clay pot rice (my favorite), Chinese sausage variety (mom's favorite), and a combo (my brother's favorite) There is complimentary soup, just ask for it. The staff is comprised of husband, wife and I presume son? The food is what makes the restaurant so good. Let me be more specific, it's the quality of the food here that makes this restaurant's food so good!!! If you are in the S.F. area or just visiting, this is a place to try and taste some really good clay pot rice. A few words of advice.. when you do order it.. finish it.. and then scrape the crust. (faun-jew). It's so good. IT's what makes the clay pot rice experience so magical.
author: Arthur W.

description: This restaurant is really a mom and pop's restaurant. The furniture inside is not in the greatest condition and the waitresses there are not as attentive as they can be. They don't speak fluent English, but what they know is how to make is some damn good claypot rice. Please don't go there if you are in a time crunch. Please don't complain if it takes long for your claypot to come. It requires time to cook rice, so if you have to wait 20-30 minutes for your food to come it's completely normal. Once the claypot comes, be careful! Everything is piping hot in there! Scoop some rice and add jalepno soy sauce into your rice and you'll be enjoying the best claypot rice in the Bay Area. I recommend ordering the claypot chicken rice and the claypot pork patty and salty fish, those are my top two choices. I love it when their rice is piping hot and in the bottom of the claypot, the rice is crunchy! They also have seafood, spare ribs, frog legs, etc. pick and choose what you like but don't expect it to come quick. I recommend this place to anyone who likes piping hot food, if you're not one of them, this might not be the place for you. They also have other basic menus any other Chinese restaurant would sell, worth a try but I don't think it will not be as good as other places and won't be as good as the claypots there.
author: pooky b.

description:
I've been coming to this place since they opened their previous location. They serve authentic Taisan food (clay pot rice is their specialty). 

I always get the clay pot rice #7 (spareribs, sausage and pork) and a veggie. My second favorite is prob the chicken clay pot rice. Don't forget to eat the crispy rice on the bottom of the pot!
author: Jennifer P.

description: I was having high hope for this place. Let's talk about environment. Place clean and nice environment. Service good. But food, all tasted very plain, which I personally can cook better. I'm am authentic Chinese that loves Chinese food. That's why when come to Chinese cuisine, I'm very particular. Food using very basic seasoning, salt, soy sauce, and pepper. That's it. I can't taste any other interesting flavour. Not even oyster sauce, Chinese wine or sesame oil etc. Really disappointed. I won't come back. Nice service tho
author: Unyo N.

description: I got the number 6 like everyone said to. It was a big pile of meh. Yes it had flavor, but that just came from the duck sausage. Basically the dish tastes like duck sausage. Also they have me a jug of soup and I ladeled some in a cup to drink. When they served my dish they confiscated the not-empty jug of soup. I really wanted that soup, but I noticed too late. I'm writing this review as I wait for them to notice I'm done. It's been like 20 minutes. I'm just sitting here typing this review. This could be a fun game actually, where I just write terrible things about them until someone comes and helps me. I think you'll agree that it's only fair. So, what else. Some of their patrons are annoyingly loud and vapid to boot. Like, shut up about growing up Asian already, we all did it, you're not unique. Just like a millennial to expect attention for something so normal. So what your parents made you play the violin. Unless you're in an orchestra I don't want to hear about it. I wonder if I make eye contact this guy will come over and give me my bill. I mean, I bet I could just walk out of here and no one would notice. You know that old adage that the worse the service in a Chinese restaurant, the better the food? I found the exception to the rule. That sentiment has hereby been debunked. Not true. And who the f*ck serves toothpicks in a Parmesan cheese shaker!? These guys do. Also their chopsticks are this weird shade of orange. Like they were once bamboo but have petrified over the years. I mean, it's just not attractive. Get some fresh chopsticks. Oh man, the couple who came in some time after me just got their bill. They must know some secret that I am not privy to. Or maybe they're personal friends, but I doubt it since they look like they're from Minnesota and should be eating hot dish or whatever it is they eat up there. I just pushed my plate a little further away from me. Maybe that's the secret. No one's around to see it though, so I might be here a while. Strap on a seatbelt folks this ride might be longer than you expected. Crap the waiter just walked right by me like I'm not even here. Holy crap. Am I dead? Did I get food poisoning, pass out, and die? Am I doomed to haunt this joint for the rest of my life? What kind of special hell would that be? Haunting a restaurant, forever waiting for a bill that never comes? Knowing that my last meal was basically over-cooked duck sausage?  Well, isn't that special. The next table just got their jug of soup. I'm watching carefully, buster. Now I'll finally know if you confiscate soup jugs from everyone or just me. Man that lady has waaaay to much makeup on. I'm getting a stomach ache -- that must mean I'm still alive, right? Not sure if that's a good thing because I pretty much wish I was dead right now. Where's my goddamn bill?! Tick tock mother f'rs my time is money. My mind is on my money and my money's on my mind. Badum-chick! Thanks for the laugh folks I'll be here all night. Be sure to try the roast beef! (Because the duck sausage is questionable). Oh man their dishes came out and THEY STILL HAVE THEIR SOUP JUG. WTF. I was robbed. Just plain robbed. I want my soup dammit. You know what, I was gonna be generous and give you guys two stars but I'm just gonna have to change it to one at this point. Man that waiter Just. Won't. Make. Eye. Contact. Why so shy buddy? I don't bite. La la la la.  LALALALALALALA. HOLY MOTHER OF GOD HE JUST SAW ME. This is it, folks, he handing me my bill! I am so happy! Ok, so, um. It's been real. Later.
author: Mike M.

description:
Their new location is much more spacious and can accommodate more tables than before.

While the servers are a bit inexperienced, the owners are very hands on and make sure their customers are taken care of. 

The clay pots are great, the duck is a must and the salt + pepper tofu is pretty bomb.

It didn't take us that long to get our food unlike what other Yelpers said. $34 for 3 dishes. Not that pricey although some dishes can run up to $14.95 and larger clay pots can be $38.
author: Julie L.

description:
The claypot is really yummy!!! 
But I can not stand the environmentt & sanitation, I see a insect landed on the plate!!! That is REALLY disgusted!!! I will not going there next time. I don't think they gonna pass the Health inspection.
author: Yvonne L.

description: If you like the crunchy rice that lines the bottom of the rice pot then you'll love this place!! I got the spare rib clay pot and the sauce they put on the rice is so good!!! The only downside is that it takes quite a while and they give you a lot of rice and not much meat. We also ordered the pig stomach and salt and pepper fish that were pretty good too.
author: Linz C.

description:
The Claypot House is the former Taishan Cafe from down the street. there's confusion above nameage since they still use the old Taishan Cafe menus.

eats:house special home made lamb stew in claypot(6.95)
-big vessel of homemade "cole" (dried bok choi?) soup gratis
yummy!
-tender lamb stew premade, placed in claypot and baked
rice came out crusty ala dolsut bibimbap without the veggies
only drawback, dish tasted greasy, couldn't finish.

takeouts:'
-fab value
-not much service, didn't need much, helped myself to take home box.
seems only 1 waiter, owner, and "go-fer"
4 stars for value and home cooking, service is neglible, be aware.
-eels, frogs, taishan specialites on back menu.
author: Victor G.

description:
So disappointed tonight.

-lackluster service (2 waiters on a busy Sun night...really?)
-both pots of rice didn't have the nice burnt bottoms that it's supposed to
-turtle dessert was days' old.
author: Lisa C.

description:
We happened to wander in on opening day. Not surprisingly, things were a bit confused and unpracticed, so this review is going to overlook those sorts of things.

Before we ordered, a big crock of tofu skin / corn / chicken soup arrived. It was good -- simple, but nice enough. It wasn't very hot, though, a detail that I imagine the Health Department will ding them for before long.

Hot tea arrived, except that it, too, wasn't very hot. In fact, it was practically luke-warm. More interestingly, it was a pu-erh tea, not the usual Oolong you get in Chinese restaurants. I thought that this was a nice touch -- if you like pu-erh as I do. (Otherwise, one might just think that it's dirty-tasting tea.)

We ordered three things:

Sweet and Souse (sic) Chicken for the daughter unit. This was good enough for its genre. Simple, not too syrupy. Sweet and Sour Chicken just isn't my bag, though.

Two clay pots:
#3 eel, frog & Chinese sausage, preserved pork and duck
#6 spareribs, preserved Chinese sausage, pork and duck

These are generous portions of rice put into a super hot clay pot so that the bottom gets brown and deliciously crispy, with whatever meats and whatnot placed on top. They were both straight-forward, simple and enjoyable.

The three of us ate more than we needed and brought some home for $36, including tip. That may be the cheapest dinner in SF. 

By my math, this meal earned a solid three stars+. Since it was opening day and because of the great value, I think they deserve a benefit-of-the-doubt and thanks-for-the-cheap-eats fourth star, at least for now.
author: Todd H.

description:
I think 90% of the chinese population here in San Francisco are from Taishan, a small village in Canton province of China (I might be wrong about the % but its close to) therefore Taishan Cafe is one of their fav spot for dinner. If you ever go there make sure you have a friend with you whom speaks Cantonese or Mandarin so you wont have trouble ordering. There are numerous times where I see people who doesn't speak Chinese having a hard time understanding the waiters or having trouble placing an order. Maybe that is the reason why they have pictures of the dishes on the menu. 

Also don't mistake the big picture hanging on the wall as TaiShan in China that is actually a night view picture of HongKong from back in the 90s! I don't know why Chinese restaurants around the bay area who names their restaurant after a Chinese city always hang a picture of HongKong or Beijing? That is so so misleading. What if some of us really thought that is actually taishan and ended up going there and find out that Taishan is a small beat up village.... Imagine what a shock that will be....On the left side of the wall it has a chinese saying which translates to: You can try all the delicious cuisines around the world but your hometown cooking still tastes the best! I think I totally agree with this. 

Now move to the dishes, all their clay pots are good and if you are adventurous try the yellow eel clay pot, it is pretty good and also one of their big sellers.  The rice wrapped in lotus leaves are very good also a must try! No matter what you order the restaurant will throw in the soup of the day and some chicken feet, both taste greeeat!

Overall a great place for some different style of Chinese food. You will either like this place or hate it. 

Don't be shocked that you might be the only none Chinese in this place and when this place is full it is LOUD! Chinese speaks loud but even louder when they speak in Cantonese! One last advice: during weekdays avoid going there during lunch time, apparently this place is filled with Taishanese contractors during lunch time, no offense but they are all wearing dirty work cloth and the smell of paint and sweat will totally ruin your appetite! One more thing, don't expect any good service there, you are on your own!
author: William C.

description: Terrible service!! mixed seafood tofu clay pot was sour! We ask for new one, but we only got oily tofu! Wtf!
author: vivian l.

description: Today I come to this place for lunch order porkchop & salt n pepper as you can see the picture I post there are more fat porkchop in plate taste with plain no salt ... Looking good but taste nasty so any fat !! N it's cost 12.95?! Clay pot  so little for 9 $ taste okay thou
author: Linh D.

description:
I love their claypots! Ive been here many times and all the times I ate here the food is always bomb.com!! 

They have different sizes for their claypots which could accommodate a bigger party, thats a plus! My quick tip for you newbies out there is once you get to the bottom of your rice claypot, pour the complimentary soup in there and let it soak so the crunchy rice on the bottom could come off easily... So good!!! 

I never let asian resturaunt service turn my experience into a negative one because 

1.im just there for their food
2.this aint no 5 star resturaunt (who you foolin')
3. If the food is good... Its all good.
4. You get what you pay for...the food.

I would recommend coming here on a slow day so you can enjoy the food, the workers are honestly really nice! Just a lil fluster minded sometimes but its all good!
author: Sophia T.

description:
This is the new location for what was previously called "Tai Shan Restaurant" which was located one block on Clement Street near Funston and was damaged by a fire at the neighboring church one day.  My friend and I missed the old location when it closed and was very happy to see it reopen at this newer location.  The Cantonese name is still the same but they changed the English name.  The restaurant space is larger with more tables than at the old place.  I also see they brought the old staff over (at least the ones I can recognize from before).

The menu appears the same as before (including the prices).  My favorite is still the preserved meat clay pot rice.  They still provide sauce with peppers inside which I love adding.  The house soup they provide is great also.

This place is now "Cash Only".  Before they accepted credit cards when at the former location.

I gave five stars to the old location's listing and review.  Here I still give it five stars, especially they have a much nicer interior.
author: H K.

description:
The only reason I give this 3 stars is because the owner of the restaurant is super friendly and actually tries to talk to his customers. Very welcoming personality! Another plus for the complimentary soup that was decent, but I think my mother's soups are better. 

We ordered veggies to pair with two order of claypot rice entrees. I came here with my mom and sister, so two orders of the claypots were more than enough for us. My mom ordered the preserved meats claypot which came with various meats and  the house special claypot (frog, eel and lap churng). I was definitely not a fan of it because there wasn't enough flavor. I had to add their spicy soy sauce (which they have on every table) in order to enjoy my meal. I didn't like the house special since I don't eat most of the stuff in that dish. My favorite part would be the crispy parts of the rice where it's on the side of the claypot. I don't think I will be returning, since I have definitely gotten better elsewhere. 

Oh yeah, it's also cash only!
author: Amanda C.

description: I've been to this location once while I was up NorCal. This is as authentic claypot rice and the best bang for your buck. There is no store parking however there is street parking available. Would recommend anyone to stop by!
author: John F.

description: Their claypot is awesome. The food is good as it can be. No comment about it. The rice at the bottom is crunchy which made that the best part. I come here once in a while and every time I revisit the place, I would order the same as always. I came there at night most of the time and it gets crowded but the wait wasn't as long.
author: Christina L.

description:
***CASH ONLY***

2 stars because:
1) Service is TERRIBLE. Even for a Chinese restaurant. It is so bad. Luckily, we beat the dinner rush by a couple of minutes. Got seated quickly for a table of 2. Received tea upon sitting down, which is not so bad. Waited 10 minutes to put in our order. The tables that sat down later than us received their complimentary soup first. Food came out surprisingly quick though...

HOWEVER, we requested the check and the waitress came up to us to confirm that we wanted our check. Over 5 minutes passed and no sight of our check or any waitresses. Finally, the waitress passed by and we made eye contact with her. NOTHING...So I went up to her to request the check again. I think she finally realized that she forgot our check and apologized. 

2) Food is not as good as it used to be. We ordered #7 (Preserved Chinese Sausage, Pork, & Duck) and the eggplant fish clay pot. 

Our #7 looked okay...I guess, seemed like they skimped on the meat though. Not to mention it hardly had any taste. We used quite a bit of the spicy soy sauce just to taste something. Mmmmm msg and sodium. Nomz (sarcasm)

The eggplant fish clay pot was pretty good. It was a decent amount but it was more expensive than our #7. At least the flavors were on point. 

Long story short, I'm not coming back here. It felt greasy and dirty in there, poor ventilation, and horrible service for not so tasty food.
author: Rebecca T.

description:
Not sure what all the negative reviews are about, because this place never disappoints.

The complimentary soup is delicious, their entrees are extremely tasty, and the wait staff are very kind.

I would highly recommend!
author: Meaghan H.

description: for the food it was no problem. the reason why i give one star is that they cheat us in the price. i order three items from their manu with price，and i clearly remenber the price， but when i asked for check，they gave me the bill，and i found that two  dish they over charged for $2， totolly over charge $4，but they just minus $2 after i told them，it is very dishonest，very ugly ways. never come back，i don't like such cheating business，the other guys who is the first time pls pay attention to your bill before you pay！！
author: Derick L.

description:
This is the worst claypot I have ever have.  They gave tones of tasteless white rice, hardly any meat.  My friend's eel pot was very small, skinny and pricy and the rice  was burned black at the bottom.  The eel portion was way smaller than in the picture.  They don't have desert, owner need to take it off of the menu.   Will never go back to this place.  I think the one in Chinatown is better.   
So sad to see this restaurant still exists in Richmond.    One thing about many chinese restaurant they have no quality control.  You have to count on your luck.
author: Lucy J.

description: Our friends suggested this place for lunch, so we decided to give it a try. Started with a complementary soup, nothing fancy, tasted ok. We ordered a frog's leg & chinese bacon rice pot and I wasn't impressed. My friends enjoyed it but I didn't. The dish had no flavor and tasted very bland. Menu very limited, concentrating on clay pots.
author: Roland F.

description:
I went here for lunch and ordered the Mixed Seafood Claypot over rice... and was not impressed at all. It was way over priced @ $12.95 on the Menu handed inside. What I got was 3-4 pieces of shrimp, a few tiny scallops & some pieces of squid on top of some rice. It seemed to be cooked with nothing more than what was thrown into the clay pot. It came with a small plate of some leafy greens that looked like scraps. -- I wished I had taken a picture of this pathetic dish, so you can see for yourself.

Perhaps I made the mistake of ordering the most disappointing dish on the menu. However, I would not go here again and would not recommend this place.
author: Rico T.

description: I come here for food, not for service.  The clay pot rice is very authentic.  I grew up in HK and service at this type of restaurant is never a priority.  So I don't understand why ppl talk more of service than food.  Rice is the biggest component of this clay pot rice dishes because the crusty rice is the whole idea!! It's so weird to see all these complaints about the portion of rice here (aren't you surprised by the American portion!?). If you ever ate clay pot rice in HK or China, the toppings are just adding flavor to the rice.  The rice is actually the main dish!
author: Carla C.

description:
Listen, I don't write reviews often - and when I do, they're either for phenomenal restaurants or extremely horrible service. This is for ridiculously poor service

Took a while to get seated and we waited SO long to get our order taken, even after calling them over more than 4 times. In addition, everyone else received complimentary soup except for us. 

Poor service is enough to deter me away from a restaurant. And in addition the soup wasn't even good.
author: Clare C.

description:
If you come here for service, hah, you're out of luck. Its a chinese joint.
If you come for the food, its amazing. Best claypot I've found in SF.
So just go.
author: Julie C.

description:
Main points: 
-Long wait times for food, ordering. 
-Food tastes good. 
 We came here as two people. Signed our name on the wait list. Got a seat quickly. We tried to order the food but we had to ask multiple times to multiple people before finally someone took our order. 
It took a few minutes and we got our soup and tea. Then the wait began. 
After about 30 minutes, the boss told us to move tables so they can use our small table to merge into another table for a bigger family. At the 40 minute mark, we finally got our vegetables. At the 50 minute mark, we got our claypot rice. The food actually taste really good. The rice was great. The amount of food was decent. 
Summary: It's a nice place to eat at if you have a lot of time on your hands.
author: Herman X.

description: Really not that good at all. The cheapest clay pot rice was $8.99 but you basically get a ton of rice and not much anything else. A traditional clay pot rice will come with a thick blend of soy sauce on the side, but this place has none. Really regret going to this place since I had high hopes it would taste like the one's you get from Mongkok, Hong Kong.
author: Ken Y.

description:
Came here on a Saturday night... at 8pm and there was a half hour wait. I've passed by this place since it opened and didn't realize it was so popular. 

Before coming here, I thought my mom makes this stuff, how much better can it be? Well the answer is, it's not. They have a large random variety of choices of meats and etc. That's great and all but out of the three claypots we got, the ratio of rice to meat was ridiculously uneven. There was very little meat to go with the rice. The only awesome part is that the rice around the claypot is crispy, but what I am to do with the regular rice when there's no more meat to eat with it? 

You also get a complimentary soup... it's ok, kinda bland but filled with random veggies and a little meat. 

The owner seemed to be really friendly. He'd come around to see how we were doing and walked around to other tables. The other service staff seemed to not speak English well... and I guess that's ok given that the restaurant was filled with only chinese people but then what about the people who want to come in and eat who don't speak Chinese? 

My mom can make this better at home and that's where I draw the line with it comes to good food. If my mom can make it better, why am I paying someone else to cook for me?
author: Jeannie L.

description: Wonderful place for Taishan People. Clay-pot dishes are very close to authentic Taishan local flavors. A lot of traditional Taishan  dishes, like pig-stomach-chicken soup, five-flavor duck, lotus-leaf steamed rice, and etc. Coming back regularly and the food is still as good as it gets. Recommended to have a try.
author: Xx Z.

description:
This is a recent discovery for Dono and me. The food is delicious. We always order the chicken and mushroom clay pot and preserved salty vegetables and pork clay pot. The only issue I have is the wait. Because clay pot takes a considerate amount of time and each item is cooked to order, the wait can be quite long, ranging from 20-40 minutes on a weeknight. 

Nonetheless, I still love this place because it feels like family since it has a Taishan theme. The panoramic photo of Taicheng against the wall is very reminiscent.
author: Henry P.

description:
When they moved here there were long lines people waiting to eat there.  I forgot exactly when.  Well we finally found time to eat there.  We went there on a Saturday at 5 pm. There were no more lines of people waiting and just a few people eating inside.  We just thought that we were just too early.  

After looking at the menu and deciding we called over the waiter and tried to order our choices.  The male waiter finally came over after 15 mins of waiting and we told him what we wanted to eat.  Well, it was disappointment after disappointment.  We tried to order a vegetable dish....three times the waiter told us they are out of them.  3 out of 3 green leaf vegetable dishes were sold out.  Mind you, this is 5pm on a Saturday.  We had to settle for a cucumber sprouts dish or whatever it was as that was the only veggie dish available.

We ordered 3 clay pot dishes and when we got them, there was barely any meat in them.  Mostly sauce and rice.  The other dish we ordered was that chinese bacon dish and again a major disappointment.  The bacon was hard, not soft at all.

My 92 year mother who is from Toyshan, CN, said it was the worse chinese food she ever ate.  And chinese food is pretty much all she eats.

We will never go there ever again and trust me, you don't want to go there either.

Rule of thumb...when a restaurant barely has enough food inventory stock,  it's a bad sign.  Either they don't make enough to pay their bills  or it's very bad management.

I pass by this place every day.   Seems to be less and less business.  Guess I'm not the only one who knows how bad this place is.
author: Acura Nsx T.

description:
I don't like giving bad review, but the service was SO bad that I have to give one. 

We (2 adults, 1 toddler, 1 baby) went yesterday evening around 6.30pm, ordered 4 items ( 1 claypot rice, 1 steamed rice in lotus leaf, 1 veggie, 1 seafood). 3 items came out fairly quick, and we happily ate our food.

I checked with our server twice if the lotus rice is coming soon since we almost finished out plate. she said it is. Then another sever put a dish in our table, which was not what we order ( she put pork dish and we order rice dish). I told our server thats not what we ordered and she took it back to the kitchen, and said the rice is coming. The rice finally came when we finished our food. 

Then, when we're about to pay, they said cash only their card machine doesnt work...they did NOT put anything on their door notifying the customer. have we known that we would not have eaten there. My husband had to drive few blocks to get money from ATM while the kids and I waited in the resto. 

While waiting I checked our bill, feel a bit weird as the total for 4 items came out as $49 and each items priced at $10.95 and above. I looked at the menu and there were TWO items they overcharged us. the veggie was $7 and the Lotus rice was $6. I talked with an old guy who took my order (owner?) and he said the calculations were right. I explained that was not the same with the price on the menu. I mentioned what we ordered, he MAGICALLY remember that the price were wrong and corrected it. Did not even apologize ONCE. 

So my two cents is check your bill before you pay, especially if the old guy take your order. As for us, we will NOT come back. The food is not bad, but it's NOT that good either.
author: Caroline V.

description:
Food: 5/5
Price: $
Portion: 5/5
Appearance: 3.5/5
Presentation of food: 5/5
OVERALL: 5/5

I have been coming to this place since their previous hole in the wall location, which was like half a block down, and its been my fave! Whenever I am looking for some home cooked, memory lane to childhood dishes I come here:

 If you are looking for the most original form of Toishan cuisine...This is as AUTHENTIC as it gets!

 I always order the CLASSIC pork, duck, and chinese sausage clay pot. Once I get near the bottom of the pot, I ask them to put some soup in the pot so I can eat the bottom crunchy bits of the rice with the soup. That's THEE way to eat it right! The rice is always so flavorful and has that nice crisp near the end. You have a variety of 3 sizes, a mini, a regular, and a large (serves up to 3-4 people).

They usually give a house soup which is a clean wintermelon, carrots, bean soup. (Great soup to cure a hang over to be honest).

 I also tend to order their SALT & PEPPER shrimp, which is crispy; nicely salted, good enough where I just eat the head as well even with the shell on!

Don't forget to get your greens to balance out all the flavors, I usually get their Dao Miu; which is the freshest and most flavorful I ever eaten!!
author: Eva H.

description:
Formerly known as Taishan Cafe, this place is located across the street, a block away from the old location. Located on the corner of Clement and 11th. 

When I first found out the old location was closed down, I was devastated. I kept asking myself and my bf, "What happened? Why did it close down?!" Even though he was totally clueless about it cause he's never been there. When I found out that it got "rebranded" and I found a new review for it, I thought "Omg yay!! There's hope! Someone said it's newly open!" After arriving, I was welcomed with the boarded walls and windows .. and now I was sad again. I looked around in hopes of finding a new place - nothing. I saw a restaurant a block away, on the corner of 11th and Clement, that looked brand new. I told my bf I wanted to check it out but all he wanted to do was leave and go to Gordo's. I got in the car and as I started to drive off, I drove by the new restaurant. I saw the name "The Claypot House" outside and I yelled in glee "OMG! It's the claypot house!! This is their new location!!!" Yayy!! IT LIVES ON! 

My bf and I came on a Sunday night. There was plenty of parking in the area. The restaurant crowd was quite packed. My bf and I had to share a big table with another couple .. a little awkward but as long as we were seated immediately, we were fine. The decor inside the restaurant is the same as the old - same panorama pictures, same paintings. The difference compared to the old restaurant is, more big tables, so bigger seating area and bigger kitchen for the cooks. The service is good, because the owners are friendly and they always come around to check on you when they can. They have a waiting area outside. 

The night I came for my visit, they were still using the old menu. According to one review I read, they're still currently working on the new one. Whenever I come here, I like to order the #1, Taishan Yellow Eel Claypot (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/the-claypot-house-san-francisco?select=FQNlqyiX-7LWxjqG9W9A7Q#KgNnNOlvsOoM37rJAJvXGQ) [~$13]. Like every other claypot, this dish consists of crispy rice mixed with soft rice. The crispy rice is normally on the outer layer where the claypot is. This dish also has the yellow eel and sausages. Mix it, stir it, and yum!! You got some foodgasm going on in your mouth! I don't like to add sauces to my food (yes, I'm weird), but my bf added the Jalapeno-Soy Sauce (it's in a container in the middle of the table) to his rice and he said it made it taste so much better. Before the main dish arrives, they also give you complimentary soup that has tofu, corn, and some other stuff (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/the-claypot-house-san-francisco?select=FQNlqyiX-7LWxjqG9W9A7Q#9-nGhMH82biT_s7oGJCgCA). It's simple and good. I think one claypot is good enough for 3-4 people. I ate half the claypot myself and was filled by the end of dinner; I saved the other half for the next day. :) 

***Because they're still currently new, CASH ONLY!!!. They're working on their credit card machine due to the move.   

Side note: They have a mini-bar (not an area for seating) that serves beer! From what I saw, it looked like the IPA was the only one working that night. I think they're still working on it; I'm not sure what types of beer they serve.
author: Mandy G.

description:
I am writing this review as we wait for are food. The service is non existent here. I had to walk up to a waitress to ask for menus. I had to flag them down twice to just to get them to take our order. Total wait from sitting down to take our order was about 40min. This place is extremely under staffed. Tea cups are not clean. They just served us warm soup. Chicken just arrived after 35min from ordering. We ordered the 9$ salted chicken. Half the chicken was bones. The rest of the food arrived. Only one good dish. The rest are OK. And two bad dishes. 

Overall rating 1 star
author: Baldwin W.

description:
They take card now! 

We were seated right away when we entered, they took our order within 10 minutes. Complimentary soup was okay too. We ordered two pots and veggies. Took about 25 minutes for the food to come out... We had to ask them what was taking so long.
