Food was pretty good, a bit on the saltier side but not by too much. It was more than enough to feed 3 people.

Service is almost nonexistent, the only time we saw the server was when she was getting our order, giving us our food, then grabbing our bill. 

Decent place to eat, but nothing too special.  Total turned out to be about $31
author: Gloria N.

description: For those of you that know about or are interested in Cantonese regional cuisine, this place will be a real deal total treat. And for those of you that have never even heard of Toisan in Guanggdong province South China, and don't know anything at all about that place, although the restaurant itself is Chinese restaurant "generic plain," this place's menu might look to you like an article in National Geographic, complete with stunning pictures and descriptions of the most colorful foods imaginable. And sitting at one of these tables, you will feel like Anthony Bourdain. But tourist or local alike, what you will enjoy are the most amazing array of clay pots, rice pots wrapped in lotus leaf, and fantastic veggie dishes imaginable. Try the seafood rice wrapped in lotus leaf clay pot, the "tong choy" vegetable cooked with fermented bean sauce, (okay okay, stop saying "gag." It tastes way way better than it sounds in English for you uninitiated ones haha,) and the excellent chicken and chinese sausage clay pot. Oh and don't forget to save the best for last! Scrape the sides and bottom for a crispy rice treat!! Wow! Talk about childhood memories! Trust me. Toisanese Clay pot ON FLEEK!!
author: George F.

description: I did not have high aspirations for this place and I was not disappointed. My niece from San Diego wanted to get some authentic Chinese food...We actually went for another restaurant but it did not serve lunch...So we looked for the place with the most Chinese people...The waiter (owner) was great...very attentive.  Everything came out fresh and flavorful...So, It  wasn't great but it also wasn't bad...I enjoyed the experience but honestly, would not go back.
author: Mjc M.

description:
Have you tried FROG meat before?!  Here you can have frog legs in several different preparations - fried, steamed, simmered, and stir fried.  Some say frog meat tastes like chicken, but for me, the idea of eating frog meat kinda grosses me out.  

However...
I sure enjoy me some preserved chinese sausage and meats over rice in the sizzling clay pot... and this place is the best in the city... BUT it WILL cost ya!  Come in for the sizzling clay pot rice but avoid the other dishes, unless you are okay w/ msg, heavy oil and generous salt in your food.

Months later, i know i will find myself craving the sizzling rice and will find my way here again, but each time i leave feeling like i paid too much for this type of food.
author: Cando T.

description:
sizzling clay pots and yummy home style cooking.  the best treat is at the end with the bits and pieces of crispy rice! 

start off with a jug of simple pork/veges soup.  get your clay pots and dig right in.  my favorite is the taishan salted chicken claypot-salty green onion with some "yellow feather chicken."  rice was cooked nicely with a great texture-not too mushy or hard.  the crust was awesome! chewy, crunchy, delicious.

they have good asian veges like yam leaves, peashoots, tong choy, etc! love simple yet delicious food like that. 

back in the days, they would give pickles veges/chicken feet...i wish they would start doing that again!
author: Linda T.

description:
Ok food, terrible service. I would definitely recommend going there with someone who can speak the lingo, as it helped a ton with getting just their attention. We arrived there last Sunday night around 7.30pm and there was a line out the door, although nowhere to put our name down. There seemed to be only one lady running around to take names down, although it took us a good 15 minutes to get her attention, as she was the only one taking orders too. Seemed very disorganized. 

Had a couple of clay pots - the eel was great and so was the Chinese sausage with pork/duck- very traditional ingredients. While the prices seemed reasonable, there was a fair amount of bone so not as filling as it could be. We wanted dessert but despite having about 15 things on the menu, they only had 2 things when we asked about it. Despite the restaurant being about half full by the time we finished, we had to chase them to ask for service, the dessert menu and the bill. 

I haven't been to any other clay pot restaurants, but I'd rather check out other places before coming back here.
author: Lisette P.

description: Not your typical American Chinese food. So if you're looking for chow me in or won ton soup you will not find it here. But their salt and pepper fish was amazing,  free soup was refreshingly different, tofu was perfection. Definitely a change from the regular. A little dingy but friendly staff.
author: Matt A.

description:
I don't recall the last time I had this in China, but in my opinion, this is as authentic as it can get!  Definitely cleaner than the ones in China as well. 

I've been coming here every other week since I discovered it.  It gets really busy during lunch and dinner hours, but in general, the waitresses remain friendly.  You will have to work hard at getting their attention though since they're understaffed like every other Chinese restaurant.

My parents always get a pot of the eel one and I always go for the preserved meat one (unhealthy but it's heavenly).  They also give pretty well-made (good recipe) soup for free.  That part makes me feel slightly better about eating so unhealthily.
author: Emily W.

description:
What did one lesbian frog say to the other? you do taste like chicken! 

You can get your Frog's Legs here! also very good for vegetarians.
author: Kevin K.

description: Came here few times. Always order their eel rice claypot. It's good and the rice is well-cooked except when they are super busy like weekend night. Better come in weekdays and be prepared to wait for 15mins+ since the claypot takes time.
author: Hiro C.

description:
The food is awesome, period! 

I visited this place (originally 2 blocks from the current location) more than 50 times and the food never let me down! 

Moved to San Jose and still eager to drive up to the city for the clay pot rice and the special soy sauce.
author: Xiguang C.

description:
1. The claypots we had were not bad, although they could have had more meat in them. The greens were really good.

2. The place felt like it could use a good scrubbing, but maybe it is just shabby.

3. 5:30-6:45pm on a Friday evening, the place was full and there was ONE waiter. People were so frustrated waiting for their orders to be taken that they were walking out. Others stood while waiting for the change from their checks to be brought to emphasize the fact that they were trying to leave.

4. BIGGEST COMPLAINT: The bill was far higher than we expected. The greens (baby pea shots) were $12.99, while the two claypots with Chinese sausage, spareribs, pork, etc were $8.99 and $10.99. Huh? On top of this, when we asked why the prices charged were several dollars more per dish than on the menu, the poor overworked waiter shrugged and said that the menus were old and the prices have gone up. Is that even legal?
author: Sandra E.

description: This place is great during the cold weather! They will give you a nice soup appetizer, then bring out your clay pot meal. Now the rice smells great after being baked with the meat, which causes the great combination of a real clay pot meal!
author: Keith L.

description:
This is one of the worst restaurants that I won't go back again, to be very straight forward. 
After a brief wait for a Saturday lunch, it took more than 10 minutes and multiple callings for our table to be attended. When we were directed to the table, there were no plate settings. Usually, at a typical Chinese restaurant, tea is served as a first thing by default. This was not the case for us, party of four. When hot tea was Finally brought to our table, the appeared-to-be owner of the restaurant just left us a pot of tea...but there were no cups for us! We have to ask for cups and this was when he noticed we had no settings of plate, chopsticks and what not.
Among the four of us was an old grandma and a kid. We wanted try their special clay pot rice with river eel, but not sure of what size order to place. So we asked the owner, he recommended a medium size pot and we trusted him and place the order along  with four other courses. 
It took about twenty minutes for the first dish to come to our table. Long story short...food was warm and not hot, the medium size pot came very large..
Lots of left-over to be boxed up to go, and the worst part...the bill came extremely over priced! Place is just so so clean..
author: A L.

description: I waited a long time for them to recognize that we existed in the restaurant. Finally got my food and it was pretty worth the wait... for a restaurant that was half full.... in the middle of the afternoon...
author: John B.

description: Great place! The spare ribs, sausage, and duck and the salted fish and pork patty claypot rice is pretty damn good here. I also suggest the braised pork belly and the eggplant.
author: R S.

description: I call the Resturant for the snail, someone answer and say we have lots of orders,I'm say wow ok , I drove 1 and a half hour to this place , so I seat down and order , a girl say we don't have it ,its been sold out for 3days already, so I show them the phone and say is this your phone number here of the Resturant ? And than a younger guy with glasses and say we out, i say did you answer the phone?he say I didn't answer the phone, so I say who is laying? No one say a word, so we all 5 seat and eat the food is not good,  not cause I'm mad, the portion is small , the food taste ok , I expected a little bit better , The guys service is good, the younger girl is ok , after we finish eating and there is an older guy and say how is the food?, I say not good , it's ok (now I know who answer the phone , it's the owner older Chinese guy , I remember the voice ,) will not and never go to this place again.very sad driver home 1-1/2 hour , the bill came I didn't say anything and I tip 18%.
author: Wei T.

description: Worst Chinese food ever had honey walnut prawns terrible place looks dirty horrible beef would not recommend
author: helene e.

description: A few months ago we went here for dinner and ordered the standard clay pot rice dishes. They gave us complimentary soup in a big communal clay pot (pork and carrot) which was like warm but okay. At the end we finished up and the waitress came and took the dishes and unfinished soup away out of the corner of my eye I saw her go back into the kitchen and POUR THE SOUP into their SOUP POT which they had scooped the soup from IN THE FIRST PLACE. Holy shit.
author: Sydney L.

description: We ordered one rice and one dish Togo. Stood inside the restaurant for a good 40 minutes and then they told us they were out of the dish we wanted. So it took them 40 minutes to figure out they actually don't have the item. The waiter asked if we wanted to order something else we refused and left because we didn't want to wait another 40 minutes with an empty stomach. This is how they run their business....
author: Jessie K.

description: CLAY POT! Yes if you crave for clay pot, you gotta come to this place.  It's extremely difficult to make clay pot right - it gotta be served sizzling hot, while the ingredients not overcooked and the rice on the side do not form a thick crust.  The clay pot come in standard size and family size.  I especially enjoyed their taishan eel clay pot and the preserved meat clay pot.  I also love their vege mix stir fry and some other dishes.  Also house soup is complementary too!
author: Johnston C.

description: I am a claypot rice fanatic since I was a child in Hong Kong. I am so glad this place finally open after they moved from their old location. My favorite claypot was the salty fish and meat cake rice. I also tried their eel claypot rice which was a bit pricy, it was not bad but didn't like the eels that much. The service was kind of slow for a Sunday afternoon, and they forgot to put in an order for us. Otherwise, this place is the bomb for claypot rice.
author: Elaine C.

description:
I do not have much experience with clay pot, but I thought the food was great.
The service is very friendly and quick.
The down side....BRING CASH because they don't take credit card =P
Sometimes they don't have certain vegetables on the menu, you would have to ask them what they have today. 

Prices are fair for main dishes $9-11$ depending on the clay pot.
Vegetable are a little more expensive $9 a plate..

Nice place to eat.
author: James T.

description: The claypots are good, but the rest of the meal are pretty mediocre, and the service is really really bad, they are extremely understaffed.
author: Cheng C.

description: I know I shouldn't expect good service at a Chinese restaurant but this is by far the worst I have ever experienced. I walked in by myself for lunch, seated for at lease 10 minutes with no menu and all the staffs ignoring me. After I ordered, the waitress delivered the complimentary soup in a big pot but did not give me a bowl to eat with. I waited patiently then asked for something I can put my soup in from 3 different people and they ignored me. I know I don't speak Chinese but this is just plain rude.
author: apirada n.

description: The food served here is very close to the authentic "Toishan" clay pot rice in Canton, China.  They cook the rice from scratch inside the clay pot so you end up with a nice crispy burnt layer of rice at the bottom which tastes wonderful by adding soup.  You end up with something similar to the Northern China dish "sizzling rice soup".  Most of the other food items they offer are also close to the "Toishan" authenticity.  So food wise, I have no complaints.  BUT, I have run into more than one occasion where price gouging is a problem with this restaurant.  On one occasion, I ordered the Pig's Feet in Vinegar for takeout and upon pick up, I inquired if there's an egg inside, and I was told that yes there's one egg but I could add additional eggs if I want to.  So I ask to add one egg to the order.  This dish was originally promoted on the window as $5.75 but my bill came out to $6.95 without adding the egg.  With the addition of the egg, I was billed $8.95.  Hmm, $2.00 more for a hard-boil egg.  Ok.  I won't order the next one with the egg addition...  Today, I ordered another take-out dish:  steamed pork patty with preserved veggies on top.  When I picked up the dish, I was charged $16.40 and when I stated that it's pretty expensive, the person looked at the menu and promptly charged me $14.00 instead.  What's going on???
author: Jimmy C.

description: Just bad.  Hong Kong milk tea is just water and sugar and brown color.  The dishes never looked like the ones shown in menu.
author: Francis W.

description: Came and ordered the Spareribs Clay Pot for around $7-8. It tasted great. You also get a small pot of soup with your order. I remember eating this at their old location down the same block. You have to add in the chili soy sauce to add the kick to it. The rice on the bottom is still as crunchy as I have remember it to be. I always like eating the crunchy rice bits. For some reason, I felt like the spareribs were a bit under cook than the usual. Maybe it was just an off day for them? For a Chinese restaurant, it's clean since it's opened not long ago. I hope it stays that way.The inside looks more modern than the old location as well. Overall, I was pleased with the clay pot and the warm service.
author: Tony C.

description: Yay, they are back! Will come again and take mom here. Old school village. yes, clay pots generally take about 20 mins to make so expect to wait for the rice to be crispy. Probably going to try the stew next time. I'm a fan!
author: Thomas C.

description:
I've figured out why this place is always crowded - because nobody can leave, the service is so slow! 

After being seated for lunch, we waited a good 10-15 minutes and nobody would come take our order. After attempting to flag down our server several times, we finally walked to the kitchen and made the order there. We only had an hour so by the time the food showed up - 30 minutes later (again, after walking to the kitchen to inquire) - we had only a few minutes to eat. 

The food itself was very so-so. We had beef clay pot and crispy green beans. The crispy green beans were the best of the two. The beef clay pot had pretty good flavor but the meat was extremely fatty and full of gristle. Rice didn't arrive until we were almost done with the meal which is probably a good thing as it was very dry. I would have liked some hot sauce but, knew it would take another 20 minutes so passed.

It's not important to me but, In terms of decor this restaurant has none. It is very cluttered and messy but again, it's Chinese food on Clement, this is pretty much the norm from my experience.

Overall, the food was nothing special, it wasn't particularly inexpensive, and the service was horrendous. Since it misfired on all three measures, one star in my book. We won't be returning which is too bad as we live right down the street.

PS: Cash Only
author: Walter A.

description: I was very disappointed by this place, my rice wasn't fully cooked and the food is extremely oily.
author: Julie N.

description: misleading prices on the menu for the clay pots and the soups. also, the pork tasted spoiled.
author: Ben C.

description: The food is sub-par and overly salty. The service is horrible. Worst of all, the owner would tell us that certain item is not available. And next thing you know, the table next to us got the same dish even though they ordered after we did. We will not go back.
author: Peter T.

description: Oh claypot, a well kept secret from Panda Express and Americanized Chinese food lovers...Came here with a friend for a weekday lunch, filled with Asians, must be legit. Ordered the salt and pepper fried tofu, very good, recommend. Also ordered the house special claypot, which was a disappointment. The menu did not indicate the ingredients in the house special, but my friend is allergic to fish. We asked the overworked waitress if the claypot contained salted fish (a common item in claypots) and she said no. Ok, green light and item was ordered. When said claypot arrived, we saw...fish...not salted fish, but fish. She couldn't have spent the extra time to tell us that another type of fish was included in the house special? Oh, and the house special also contained frog, something that I wouldn't eat. So, after wasted time, we ordered another claypot-lamb claypot. We finished it like bosses. The house special was brought back home so that someone could eat it, and let's say that whatever was a sizable amount.
author: Lily Z.

description: I think this place has the most authentic home cooking I've tried to date in the US.  I was really excited to come here so my expectations were high.  Yellow eel claypot gets a B+ from me.  Roadside joints in Taishan and my mom do make it better, though.  Free soup -- YAY!!!  Snails were cooked well and the veggies were fresh and crisp.  They should really start accepting credit cards.  We are in the 2000's now...aren't we?
author: Ika M.

description: Had a great lunch here on my first visit. Everything was delicious, total Cantonese comfort food joint and the prices were great. Fed 4 adults and 2 kids for $36!!!
author: G Y.

description: First time here.  I'm giving it three stars only because of the bad service.  Long wait for everything.  Either understaffed or the waitresses aren't on top of it.  Forgot our soup, which we had to ask for half way into our meal, when we realized everyone had soup on their tables except us.  Had to wait a long time for our check as one of the other reviewers mentioned.  Had the preserved meat clay pot but there was not enough meat, also same as another reviewer said.  Owner was very pleasant.  Food very tasty.
author: Lily H.
